text:
Welcome back. We are privileged to
welcome Brandon Tseng here as our speaker.

He's the Shield AI's Co-Founder,
President, and Chief Growth Officer, along with his brother
who founded the company.

Served in the Navy-- who are Navy folks here? All right. Woo! Seven years as a SEAL
Surface Warfare Officer,

was on board the
USS Pearl Harbor. And, again, in 2015 he
founded Shield AI along with his brother.

I love the mission. It's to protect service
members and civilians with intelligent systems,
which is awesome.

And it's building
the world's first-- or world's best AI
pilot, which I think you

will hear more from Brandon on. We call him one of
the Prime slayers, along with Andrew and
a few others actually

getting out there and getting
contracts and being competitive in a system which is really
difficult to break into.

And it's just encouraging to
see folks like Brandon's company go toe to toe and succeed.

Earned his Bachelor of Science
in Mechanical Engineering from the US Naval Academy. That's like the second oldest
military academy, I think,

right? What's the oldest one? Anyone-- no, a little
interservice rivalry

as a West Pointer. And you get some
West Pointers here. Also an MBA from the
Stanford of the East, also known as Harvard
Business School.

And a little known
fact, his two daughters are named after a
weapons systems. No, daughter and my son.

Son. That's right, yeah. Which is pretty cool. One Charlie which-- anyone
heard of the Carl Gustaf

recoilless rifle system,
84 millimeter, Swedish. Does all sorts of cool stuff. I actually was the
test platoon for that

a million years ago when
I was a Ranger platooner. Amazing weapons system. So Charlie's named after that. Where's Charlie's?

That's a nickname for the-- So the British call
it the Charlie G. We call it the Carl G in America.

They call it the Charlie G. I'm sure both Charlies-- Charlie is an amazing
person, I'm sure.

And Winchester. OK, so you heard
Winchester rifles, but any Air Force people
out there or anyone

called in air support before? I have. It's when you expend
all your ammunition,

the pilot says I'm Winchester
and usually heads back to the five star
hotel and the bar.

And you're out there in
the field going, damn. But, anyways, pretty cool
names for your kids, Brandon.

What I really like
about Brandon, he's one among a
very few founders that I think is inspired by
his real world experiences,

being out there
deployed to Afghanistan and other places in harm's
way where you really-- it's a visceral experience
when you witness

a need for a technology
and a capability, because you see the
stakes, you see the impact,

the human costs of not having
that technology or capability. So I think that was
what got him, yeah,

let's go out and make money
and save our kids' college. But I think having
that experience where you see that we need
this and we need it now

and let's get after it,
make it happen, I think, Brandon is one of those
select few founders that who knows what it's like
from firsthand field experience

to need that technology. So Brandon, thanks for coming
with us, sharing stories. And, thanks, Ernestine, for
keeping the conversation up.

Awesome. Awesome. Brandon, high expectations
for your kids. But why don't we start by
talking a little bit more

about your upbringing. What inspired you to go into
service and become a Navy seal? Yeah, absolutely. And you all might laugh
at this once I get to it

but, first and foremost, I
am a sucker for inspiration. And I try to find
inspiration in lots

of different aspects of life. And so the thing that was the
spark that led to my journey

where I eventually became
a Navy seal, two movies. Favorite movies of all time,
The Rock and Under Siege,

great movies in the '90s. One is about Steven
Seagal, who's a Navy SEAL.

The plot is die hard
on a battleship. And then The Rock is
another fantastic movie

with Sean Connery
and Nicolas Cage. And, unfortunately, the SEALs
don't do well in that movie

but that's OK. It's just a movie. So those were the sparks. And then learn more about it
to ask my parents who were very

supportive to a 10-year-old
boy who's like, mom, dad, I want to be a Navy SEAL. They said, yeah, sure.

That sounds like fun. This phase will pass. And you should read books
on it because my mom

wanted me to read a lot. And so would get
my hands on books. I would read the books.

Fast forward to when I was
a sophomore in high school, I was like, mom, dad, still
want to be a Navy SEAL.

How can I do that? They said, well, you
should go to college. I said, that makes sense. And also spoke with--

we just happen to have one of
my little brother's friend's dad was a Vietnam SEAL. I asked him, how do
you become a Navy SEAL?

And he said, well, you
should become an officer. And I said, why? He's like, they make
more money, which

is the worst reason in
the world to do anything. And I can't-- that's
like poor advice. But I was like, that checked
out too, sophomore, high school.

And went to a summer program
at the Naval Academy, found a lot of
inspiration there.

Was inspired, similar
beautiful campus, great engineering program. Thought the uniforms
looked cool.

And so that was kind of the
next source of inspiration. And then even while
at the Naval Academy,

in actually seeing your-- the upperclassmen and
seeing the leaders there,

you actually learn what
service really means. And then it was,
OK, well, how do you

fast forward three,
four years there, how do you actually want to
serve your country because there are so many different
ways to serve the country

and still wanted
to be a Navy SEAL. Didn't get it right
out of the Naval

Academy, which was the best
thing that ever happened to me. But, look, that's kind of,
at the end of the day, it

was, how can I best
serve my country? And that became what
was most-- what started

as this looks really amazing. Hollywood movies became what
does service really mean, and it

was inspired about
this idea of service and what is the best way
for me as an individual

to serve my country. And that is what
led to me becoming-- wanting to become a Navy SEAL.

You were certainly an
ambitious 10-year-old. I think I wanted to be
a magician at age 10. So some of us want to be SEALs,
others want to be magicians.

But why don't you tell
us a little bit more about the founding
story of Shield AI 2015? What inspired you to
start the company?

Yeah. And, again, it's really
these stories of inspiration and being a sucker
for inspiration.

So, first and
foremost, I would point to my dad and my older brother.

My dad was an immigrant
to the United States. His family, actually-- when
the communists took over China

after World War II, my
dad and my grandparents, they fled Communist China.

They were landowners,
they lost everything and so start over from
scratch and helped establish

the Taiwanese government
and diplomatic relations with South America. And so my dad grew
up in South America

and then went to college
in the United States, and spent most of his
time in corporate America.

Actually started his
career at Bechtel, which I understand there
is a building on Stanford

for Bechtel. But at the age of
50, he wanted--

he decided to buy
a small business. And he bought a very, very
small engineering construction company.

When I say small, this is
probably like a $350,000 acquisition. And he has been working
on that for the past--

he still works on it
six, seven days a week, depending on how he feels. He loves it, which is you
can only work that hard

if you truly love something. And has been doing that for now
23 years, and will not stop.

And he will die before
he quits working. But I remember
thinking, I was like,

man, he has built this into this
really nice small business that has provided for the family,
built a level of wealth

for him and his-- my mom where he just
does it because he loves it now at this stage.

But I remember
thinking it's like-- in Harvard Business
School would describe the business is
like-- we have a term

for these businesses
like a cash bush, this was like a cash shrub. But it's a nice little--

he finds it insulting
when I call it that. But it's this really
nice business that

has provided for our family,
paid for three out of four

college tuitions,
not mine because-- and I told that to
my-- tell my parents that, you didn't pay for mine,
I went to the Naval Academy.

But I wonder, it's like,
man, what if he had just

started that business
25 years prior to starting the business
at age 50 or 30 years?

In that time that he could
have spent working on that, what could it have become?

And great credit to him, that's
just like something that I was always in my mind
but circumstances-- he

had to deal with the reality
of circumstances too. He's like, look, I had to
provide for four kids growing

up, provide for the
family, help out my aunts, my grandparents, my mom's
side, and so it was just

never in the cards for him. And he didn't want to take that
risk while raising a family. And not until we
got a lot older.

So I got a lot of
inspiration from him. The second person is my older
brother who is now the-- well, now he is the
CEO of Shield AI.

But he started his
entrepreneurial journey right out of undergrad.

So he won a small
business competition at the University of Florida. He was an electrical engineer.

It was on wireless power. Immediately went to MIT business
school right after undergrad,

where he decided to
work and start that-- make that like
senior project where

he had won this business
competition into a real company. Worked on it, sold it in three
or four years to Qualcomm.

And it was like, holy
smokes, like that is-- I have these two role models
in my life, my dad, my older

brother, who it's
like for all the risks that you hear about
entrepreneurship in every business
fails, it's like,

well, they worked
incredibly hard and I've got two examples
of success, and--

So it must be easy. So, yeah, I don't know if--
yeah, not easy, but it's like, why not? Was kind of the mentality there.

So that was kind the first
example of inspiration. The second thing,
so I was leaving the military trying to figure
out what I wanted to do.

Was going to Harvard Business
School because I didn't get accepted into Stanford,
and was just reading a lot.

My brother Ryan at the time,
he was working on an AI robot to wash dishes.

And now when I look at the Tesla
humanoid robots or the figure AI robots, it's like that
was what he's working on.

But at the time I was
like, Ryan, that is-- like, why are you
wasting your energies building a dishwashing robot?

The world's got a
lot bigger problems, and was talking about the
problems that I had experienced.

So he got me on to
reading a lot about AI, and I took a lot of inspiration
from business leaders

during that time,
Elon Musk, Jeff Bezos. One of the things-- again,
sucker for inspiration--

Elon talks a lot about-- if
you look at his old interviews he's like wanted to focus on
three things, the internet,

space travel, and
renewable energy. And you can see internet,
PayPal, X, x.com, X now,

you look at SpaceX obviously
for space travel, and then Tesla and SolarCity
for renewable energy.

I actually throw in boring
company into space travel too because I think
we're going to be living inside these planets
for tunnel systems in Mars.

But, no, I was like, where
is he not working on? And what is-- he
fundamentally framed it

as these problems are
important for humanity, and I agree with that. And it was like, holy smokes,
I have these experiences,

and national security
and global stability are fundamentally important
to the human experience.

And, actually, something
that I walked through with all new
employees at Shield AI is I go through Maslow's
hierarchy of needs.

And if you're familiar with
Maslow's hierarchy of needs, starts with food and shelter,
then it's safety and security,

then it's loving
and belongingness. I forget what the fourth
one is, and the fifth one

is self-actualization. And I tell people,
it's like, look, by virtue of being at Shield
AI, by virtue for most of them,

by being born in the
United States of America, we get a focus on layers
three, four, and five.

Just by virtue of being
at Stanford university, I'm going to get to say you guys
get to focus on three, four,

and five. Much of the world does
not get to do that. Then you can only focus
on layers three, four,

and five if layers
one and two exist. And so, again, I
was like layer one, I was not interested
in food or shelter

but it was like,
there's this area here that is fundamentally important
for everything else on planet

Earth to be achieved. And so I tell people,
it's like, look, for advancements
in human rights,

advancements in technology,
advancements in education, advancements in
medicine, advancements

in space exploration, all
these things you fundamentally have to have security
and stability first.

That just is-- that is Maslow's
hierarchy of needs there. And so there was this area
that I was able to say,

you know what, this is an
important area for humanity

and it just so
happens that I have a lot of experience in
this national security,

global stability world. And so that was kind of my
second source of inspiration

was business leaders like
Elon Musk, Jeff Bezos. Like I was inspired by
Peter Diamandis' book Bold

at the time, and so that was it. And then the third example was
actually like my experiences

with my teammates. By virtue of being
in the SEAL teams, I had the opportunity to speak
with a number of gold star

families. If you're unfamiliar,
a gold star family is a family that has lost
a loved one in service

to this country and found their
stories absolutely inspiring. And it wasn't-- it's like
when I was reflecting on--

for GSB you have to write an
essay, what matters most to you and why. And mine was like, look,
outside of my family, what

matters most to me and why is
like just continuing to have positive impact on the world. And I got to have a lot
of great positive impact

in the Navy and the
SEAL teams, and I wanted to figure out how to
have positive impact at scale

outside of the military. And so that's third
source of inspiration.

And then I remember
thinking it's like there are a few
things that have brought me

to tears in my life. And it's like when I share
stories of my time in service,

that's like when I
actually get choked up or like telling stories of other
service members time in service.

It's like, damn,
that's what I actually care a lot about and has a
real emotional pull on me.

It's like, that is great. It's something I can work on. And despite working with
the government, which

is awfully hard, awfully
frustrating, it's like at the end
of the day, you're going to fall back on
what matters most to you.

And it's like, you know what,
having a positive impact, these problems are
I care deeply about.

And so that was kind of the
third source of inspiration for deciding to approach
my brother and say,

hey, I've got a crazy idea. That's great. That's really, really
inspiring to hear.

So as you think about how
Shield AI has grown in scale and as you founded and
scaled the company,

what were some pivotal
moments that really defined the company's trajectory? Yeah, there are a number
of pivotal moments

so I'll try to pick
maybe two or three. But the first one
that comes to mind was, actually, just like
our first contract with DIU.

And that played a pivotal moment
because it led to fundraising. And so fun story.

In 2015, I'm convincing my
brother to do Shield AI with me. He says, hey, sounds
like a noble mission.

Sounds like a really
crappy business idea, but I'll help you understand
it's a crappy business idea. Go talk to 100 people.

And me being an ignorant,
arrogant, Navy SEAL I was like, whatever. This is a waste of
time but I'll do it

if this is what it takes
to get you on board. And that is-- you
learn very quickly

that's called market discovery. And so I went and
talked to 100 people, brought him along for a
number of those conversations.

And he's like, OK, there
might be something here, but it only makes sense if we
can find someone who is truly

world class at AI and autonomy. Reached out to his MIT network,
the same name kept coming up.

Our third co-founder,
Andrew Ryder. We sent him a LinkedIn message,
we flew on a plane-- no,

he responded. Three days later
we were on a plane to Boston, met a
classroom in MIT.

Talked for hours about what our
vision was for the company, what our mission would be,
what our values were

going to be for the company, and
we started the company there. Go up to-- so that was
like a pivotal moment, but then go up to raise
money because everybody's

like that sounds like
awesome, sounds like you've got a great founding team. You guys will have no-- Ryan's got a successful
exit under him,

selling this wireless
power company to Qualcomm. You guys will have no
problem raising $5 million.

Go up to meet with 30
different venture capitalists, and they say, hey, sounds
like a really noble mission,

sounds like a crappy business. And-- Except if you were
raising now, everyone would be throwing
money at any idea.

The seed and series A
stage companies now, no. No, that was-- so it wasn't
until we got our first contract

in 2016 through the Navy,
through actually Naval Special Warfare, through
Defense Innovation

Unit did we get the traction
to raise $2.5 million

and delivering for
your investors. And so we've now raised
over $1 billion in capital,

have raised every single year
and it's been off to races. But that first contract
was super pivotal.

That first proof of sale
was super important. And it's funny because.

Defense Innovation Unit was
on the verge of not doing it. And you had a customer from
Naval Special Warfare said, hey,

DIU, you guys-- it was DIUX-- like, everybody knows you're
not going to be around next year anyway, so just give us the
money so we can do this project.

And fast forward, and now
look at what DIU has become. And I think it's incredible.

Very few people believed
in that organization also in its early stages, and
they've had to go through a lot.

The second thing I
think about was in 2021, we made two acquisitions.

We bought a company
called Martin UAV, we bought a company
called Heron Systems. And that was a pretty pivotal
moment for us because just

the defense acquisition system--
you could say the defense tech

ecosystem-- it's like
it's a very, very hard-- they call it the
valley of death. You could call it
like scaled sales.

It's very hard to
achieve scaled sales if you're not in these really
marquee programs of record.

You could-- I tell
everybody, it's like, look, there's actually
a path where you don't have to have progress
and record where you can get

to like up to $20 million
in annual revenue, but you would stall out.

And it's just really
hard to get past that. And that's actually by design of
the federal acquisition system, which you've had
a lot of defense,

large Primes lobby for in terms
of what that all looks like. And then there are a
variety of different types

of programs of record. They're not all created equal. There are great
programs of record, there are crappy
programs of record.

And I think a lot
of the people are realizing this and
understanding this that have been playing in this
space but we had a challenge.

We weren't in great
programs of record. It was hard to continue
to grow, to continue to--

we were trying to
partner with Primes to actually deploy the
technology on their platforms,

and it just became
evident that we were going to get slow rolled. And so for our stage, we
were a series C company.

And it was like, hey, we
have to fix this problem. And went to the board,
and we consolidated.

It's like, all
right, well, we're going to fix this problem
through acquisition, which is a very-- in my head-- and I'll give a
great credit to my brother.

You grow up seeing all
these companies, these-- and the last thing
you're like, no,

acquisition is for extremely
late stage companies or it's for public companies.

And we just have to solve this
problem through brute force, brute strength.

And my brother's
like, no, we got-- we should use this
lever that we have to--

that if we can pull off, it
will help solve this problem massively. And I actually love--

I think it's Ben
Horowitz's quote. He's like, this
isn't checkers, this is motherfucking
chess, which is--

it's like there are so
many different plays and you just have to
figure out which one. And so we made the decision
to buy two companies

at the same time while
concurrently raising a series D because we had no capital. And that is a rare
moment in time,

like 2021 we're talking
here, right before had this happened
a year later, it would have been a
completely different story.

Two years later,
completely different story.  And I remember one
of our investors

and board members
afterwards said like, holy crap, I
can't believe you guys just pulled that off
because in the series of about

four months we raised $225
million, bought two companies, and solved some pretty
material problems.

Not technology problems, not
product problems, but really just market problems that
existed during that time.

And so that was a
really pivotal moment. Yeah. So you've touched upon
this a little bit, but maybe you could
dive more into what

lessons you learned as the
company grew from the quadcopter to larger platforms.

Oh man, so many lessons. First and foremost,
one of the great--

I'll start with
the positive side in terms of working
with a small product, with a small customer base
being special operations

command, Naval special warfare. It was actually, quote
unquote, like the "intimacy"

that the two organizations had
in terms of bringing this new technology to the battlefield.

And it was outside of any
bureaucratic constraint. And it's like you're getting
great user feedback, we're sending our engineers
to watch their training,

see how they're
deploying it, and that is like how you actually build
products really, really fast.

And that is actually not how
the government builds or buys products or technology.

And you might be
surprised by that. It's like it's
very-- or maybe not-- but it's very bureaucratic,
it's very formal process

driven in terms of when
they're building the F-35, they're not talking to
every single fighter

pilot in the entire
market landscape. They're saying, hey, you
know what, there's only going to be four fighter
pilots that you guys are

going to work with for this. And you're not going to get any
user feedback from other people as you're building this program.

We have strict requirements to
build to these requirements. We had no requirements, like
no requirements dictated

to do outside of the
defense landscape and so we were doing it. It's like what you see every
single other big company-- not

big tech company
have done, whether it was like Google or
Facebook or Amazon,

it's like be customer obsessed,
solve their problems for them. But it is wildly different
in the defense space.

And to this day I
say, look, actually, if you're going to play in this
space, you have to do both. You have to actually go through
that formal acquisition process,

you have to be building
towards requirements if you want to do
scale and that can be challenging and frustrating. But you have to build a
relationship with the customer

also where you're getting
that intimate user feedback and building the
products that they want. And you have to find a way to
do both at the exact same time,

which adds a huge
challenge to it. Lots of other lessons
I do think about it's

like the lesson of building
programs of record versus buying programs of record.

And that not all programs
of record are equal. And it might be really
obvious to say now

but in hindsight, I think
about those challenges. Challenges as it relates
to helping your customer

base understand software
and how to price software,

how to budget for software. No, we can't budget for it
because there are no software requirements, these are all
very tactical lessons learned

over nine years of doing this. Yeah, yeah. So why don't we
talk a little bit about just decisions your AI
makes versus the human operator

and who decides on the
platform or the human

making the decisions. Yeah. So first and foremost, the
human sets the overall intent.

And there's this lexicon that
we use in the military called commander's intent.

And that is like, hey,
I'm going to give you the overarching
mission and you're going to figure
out how to do it.

And so, like, I don't know,
your parents are like-- if you're an undergrad or like
you might put this on yourself

if you're a grad student--
they may be like, my intent for you
is to go get A's. And then you got to figure
out how to go get A's in all

your classes, right. And similar-- or for a
self-driving car, which is more applicable to this, what
we do-- which is essentially

self-driving technology for
aviation-- a self-driving car you'd say, hey, your mission is
to go from point A to point B.

And I want you to figure out
everything else along the way. And that's what we
do, whether it's with a quadcopter that
is exploring buildings

and that's the intent, its
mission, whether it is an F-16, dogfighting in one v.
one, in two v. two,

and two versus many in
beyond visual range combat. You're setting that overall
mission for the user,

and the system is
figuring out how to execute it in the exact
same way a self-driving car is

figuring out how to
execute its mission. And it's breaking
down its mission into different elements
in the same way

a self-driving car does. It's like, OK, well
now I'm navigating in an urban environment and
there's stoplights and stop

signs. There's more restrictive
speed limits. I have to be cognizant of
bicycles or pedestrians,

and then I have to change
my behaviors when I am now on a freeway, our aircraft
are doing the exact same thing

in terms of figuring out
how to execute the mission. The human plays a huge
role in, really, two parts.

One is setting that
overall mission intent, but it's also like
the course adjustments

and where like I'll call it
the behaviors or the tactics

have not yet been developed
or you want it to focus. Humans are really, really good
at lots of different things

that can help systems be more
productive, faster in terms of its execution.

And I think about it, actually. It's like I was
driving to a wedding from my house, which was 45
minutes away in Annapolis,

Maryland, just last week
in my wife's Tesla Model Y. And Elon had given the full
self-driving to everybody

for a couple of months so I was
like, let me play with this. And I was like
letting it play out but it was just going too
slow in certain areas.

So I was like, god dang it. And so like, I'm
going to go faster. Like, I get what it can do. And so that's when that
like, human intuition

becomes important. And so our operators for
something like the quadcopter

might say, yeah, I know you just
mapped out this entire area, but I see wires that
otherwise would stop me.

And I'm going to dictate that
you spend some time looking at those wires because
that could be a house born

IED, that could be-- it could be anything, but
that's like the number one thing that a human would have
intuition for that.

Computer vision models
didn't exist for IED wires back in 2016, 2017.

And then the last part
of it is the employment of lethal effects
on the battlefield

or just effects on
the battlefield. Having been a CEO,
having had to make

the moral decision about
the use of lethal force on the battlefield,
I fundamentally believe that is a very
human thing to do.

It is Shield AI's policy
that any time lethal effects be employed on the
battlefield, a human

is in the loop, on the loop,
giving the system the decision

to do that. And to be clear, our
systems don't actually have those capabilities but it's
the customers will start asking.

They already have but
those capabilities will come online when we
think about the future of the battlefield.

And then the good
news is also it's like that's the United States'
policy, that's NATO's policy.

And then take it
for a grain of salt. It's like even Chairman
Xi has said, look,

he's like, no one
wants autonomous killer robots on the battlefield. And so it's like
everybody's kind of like stacking hands on that.

We'll see for what's
that worth but that's the other area that humans play
a role on in terms of decision

making with AI and
autonomy as it relates to the military context. Yeah. So outside the US
government, you're

working with other nations. How does that experience,
working with other nations compare to working with DOD?

It varies. It's positive. It's really an interesting
space in the world.

And normally I would
show a couple of charts, but I'll talk about
the interesting part. So if you had to look at the

Other aircraft drones,

have more things, you do better on whether it's
more people, more weapons,

you do better during conflict. And that's 4,000 years old,
